I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of the Kyrgyz Republic is willing to undertake comprehensive reform in 
the rural water supply and sanitation (WSS) subsector, including (i) preparation of a rural WSS 
strategy,  (ii)  implementation  of  a  rural  WSS  policy,  (iii)  the  establishment  of  strong  and 
competent  sector  institutions,  and  (iv)  the  development  of  a  framework  for  infrastructure 
development and system maintenance. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) supports these 
reforms  and  believes  they  are  necessary  for  efficient  operation  of  the  subsector.1 This  is 
reflected in the country operations business plan, 2012–2013.2   
 
2.  The World Bank is providing technical assistance (TA) to develop the rural WSS strategy. 
The proposed technical assistance (TA) will build on this strategy and implement the remainder 
of the planned reforms. ADB agreed with the government about the objectives and scope of the 
TA, the terms of reference for consultants, and the cost and implementation arrangements.3 The 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Most  of  the  rural  water  supply  infrastructure  in  the  Kyrgyz  Republic  was  built                     
40–50 years ago, during the Soviet period. As built, the water supply systems provided reliable 
services.  However,  after  independence  from  the  Soviet  Union  in  1991,  the  rural  WSS 
infrastructure  deteriorated  rapidly.  Rural  WSS  systems,  originally  operated  by  state  and 
collective  farms,  were  transferred  to  local  governments,  which  did  not  have  the  funds  or 
expertise to operate them. Most of these systems broke down or were abandoned.  
 
4.  The decline of the rural WSS sector was temporarily halted and reversed4 by the Taza 
Suu  program.5 So  far,  WSS  systems  in  506  villages  serving  1  million  people  have  been 
constructed and rehabilitated. However, the improvements achieved by the program seem to be 
short-lived. Many of the new and rehabilitated systems show signs of deterioration because of 
poor construction and lack of funds for maintenance. Furthermore, the program experienced 
implementation problems, integrity breaches, and insistence on the use of obsolete technical 
standards and solutions. Overall, the Taza Suu program was a patchwork program whose 
results are generally unsustainable.6 
 
5.  Absence  of  rural  water  supply  and  sanitation  strategy  and  policy. One of the 
primary hindrances to further development in the rural WSS sector is the absence of a rural 
WSS strategy and policy.7 The rural WSS sector lacks development direction, performance 
targets, rules and regulations, a progress monitoring mechanism, and means of correcting 
direction.  Past  efforts to  develop  a  sector  development  policy  and  a  legal  and  regulatory 
framework for rural water asset creation and service delivery, as part of the Community-Based

2 
Infrastructure Services Sector Project,8 were unrealized. However, the government commitment 
to developing the rural WSS subsector is increasing. Rural WSS has been included in the most 
recent  Kyrgyz  Republic  Medium-Term  Development  Plan,  2012–2014.  The  World  Bank  is 
developing  a  high-level  participatory  rural  WSS  strategy  that  will  outline  the  vision  for 
development of the subsector.9 This strategy will be completed by May 2013. The proposed 
activities under this TA are designed to complement World Bank efforts and to operationalize 
the vision presented in the strategy.  
 
6.  Sector  governance.  The  Department  of  Drinking  Water  Supply  and  Sewerage 
Development, under the State Agency for Construction and Communal Services (SACCS), is 
the  only  central  government  agency  operating  in  the  WSS  subsector.  This  department  is 
responsible for the development of WSS. However, it has a low level of authority and capacity, 
as it was only created in 2012 after the new government took charge. In its previous forms, the 
department was frequently moved between ministries and agencies. SACCS’s experience in 
WSS and in working with development partners is very limited. 
 
7.  Sector  operations  and  performance.  Community  Drinking  Water  Users  Unions 
manage the rural WSS systems built or rehabilitated under the Taza Suu program. Rural WSS 
systems not addressed by the Taza Suu program operate directly under local government 
administration. Rural WSS services are poorly delivered because of (i) financing gaps resulting 
from low revenues caused by low tariff bases and poor collection, (ii) asset deterioration caused 
by insufficient funds for maintenance and reinvestment, (iii) ineffective organization of service 
provision, (iv) lack of skilled personnel, (v) reliance on outdated and inefficient construction 
norms and standards, and (vi) poor sector regulation and management. The indicators are, at 
best, estimates since the users unions and rural WSS systems operated by local government 
(service providers) do not collect reliable data. The key issues are:10   
(i)  Low water supply coverage: 50%–60% in rural areas  
(ii)  Non-potable water: 2% of chemical and 10% of microbiological tests failed  
(iii)  Insufficient hours of supply: 4–20 hours of water supply per day 
(iv)  High water losses: Level of losses is unknown, but estimated to be 35%–45% 
(v)  Low sanitation coverage: Less than 25% of rural population  
 
8.  ADB  support  for  water  supply  and  sanitation.  Since  2001,  ADB  has  provided 
$66 million  for  rural WSS  projects  in  the  Kyrgyz  Republic,  including  the  community-based 
infrastructure project and the Supplementary Community-Based Infrastructure Services Sector 
Project, financed by both loans and grants. Both of these projects faced major implementation 
difficulties. Implementation issues in the community-based infrastructure project included (i) cost 
overruns; (ii) weak administration; (iii) poor selection of subprojects; (iv) poor performance of 
consultants, design institutes, and contractors; (v) poor execution of works, with substandard or 
even secondhand equipment being installed; and (vi) poor sustainability of subprojects. To

ADB suspended the project in May 2012.11 
 
9.  External assistance. In addition to ADB, the Department for International Development 
of the United Kingdom (DFID) and the World Bank have supported projects in rural WSS 
through (i) the  World Bank- and DFID-funded Rural WSS 1 and 2 projects (part of Taza Suu), 
and (ii) the World Bank-funded Small Towns project. All of these projects faced implementation 
problems. DFID withdrew from the rural WSS because of poor results of the Taza Suu program. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
10.  To address the identified deficiencies, it is proposed to support the creation of a robust 
governance framework and institutions for the rural WSS subsector—to enable the execution of 
the rural WSS strategy, which is currently being prepared. The proposed TA will focus on four 
main areas: 
(i)  Build  a  strong  institutional  framework  by  clearly  defining  the  roles  and 
responsibilities of institutions and building their capacity to fulfill those roles and 
responsibilities.  
(ii)  Prepare a rural WSS policy that will create an enabling environment for the delivery 
of sustainable, good quality WSS services at a reasonable cost.  
(iii)  Synthesize  lessons from  past  experiences  by  building  on  reports  prepared  by 
ADB’s Kyrgyz Republic Resident Mission to include technical aspects of projects, 
project management aspects, and projects from other development partners.  
(iv)  Monitor  the  implementation  of  the  government’s  demonstration  activities  and 
assess the quality of designs and construction, and sustainability. 
 
11.  The  first  two  tasks  are  expected  to  improve  rural  WSS  sector  governance,  and 
subsequently, sector performance. They will address the sector-wide problems identified in the 
risk  assessment  report.  A  strengthened  institutional  framework,  combined  with  capacity 
development, will strengthen or create institutions to be able to fulfill their roles and deliver high 
quality WSS services effectively. To achieve this, the proposed TA will (i) define the approach to 
filling the governance gap; (ii) design a rural WSS institutional framework to include all levels, 
from  national  level  institutions  to  village  level  service  provision;  (iii)  define  the  roles  and 
responsibilities of these institutions; (iv) design mechanisms to minimize corruption; (v) define 
the capacity development needs of institutions; and (vi) design and deliver essential training.  
 
12.  The rural WSS  policy  will  give  the  institutions the  mandate,  authority,  and  tools  to 
operationalize the rural WSS strategy. Rural WSS policy will include (i) regulatory and service 
monitoring  mechanisms  (including  revised  water  quality  standards);  (ii)  tariff  and  subsidy 
mechanisms; (iii) revised rural WSS technical standards (i.e., compatible with standards of 
international water associations); (iv) operation and maintenance (O&M) plans and guidelines; 
(v)  rural  WSS  asset  ownership  regulations;  (vi)  a  standardized  design  approach  and 
                                                
11 ADB. 2012. Project Procurement-Related Review Report for the Supplementary Asian Development Fund Grant to 
Kyrgyz Republic for the Community-Based Infrastructure Services Sector Project. Manila.

4 
procurement plans for rural WSS systems; (vii)  a benchmarking and information gathering 
program; (viii) a WSS professionals training plan; and (ix) sector coordination, support, and a 
knowledge-sharing plan. These first two tasks will create a solid sector governance framework. 
As a result, stronger and more competent institutions will apply these policies and improve 
sector performance through the enforcement of new service standards, O&M guidelines, tariffs 
and subsidies, and through improved capacity, knowledge sharing, and information availability. 
 
13.  The second group of tasks will improve project implementation. The report on project 
lessons, building on risk assessment and procurement review reports, will add technical, project 
management, and compliance perspective to the existing work. It will also add lessons from 
other development partner projects and include a willingness-to-pay survey. The report on 
project lessons will provide guidelines on how to address identified implementation problems.  
 
14.  The government is planning a series of demonstration projects and rectification actions, 
to be designed by the Department of Drinking Water Supply and Sewerage Development. They 
are meant to rectify the non-functioning or poorly functioning subprojects financed by ADB 
under the Taza Suu program and to ensure these subprojects deliver acceptable levels of 
service. The government will, at its own cost, finance all the equipment and civil works required 
to make these subprojects operational. These projects are meant to demonstrate that the 
government has the capacity to implement rural WSS projects successfully. The proposed TA 
will monitor and assess the government demonstration projects and rectification actions by 
(i) conducting  a technical  review  of the  designs  and  systems  as constructed,  (ii) gathering 
community feedback about the projects, and (iii) analyzing project finances to ensure financial 
sustainability.  The  findings  of  this  activity  will  be  used  to  guide  subsequent  programming 
financed by ADB in rural WSS. 
 
15.  The government requested the proposed TA, and it is included in the country operations 
business plan, 2012–2013.  
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
16.  The impact of the proposed TA is delivery of improved rural WSS services. The outcome 
of the TA is the establishment of institutional arrangements for rural WSS services. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
17.  The outputs will be prepared in close coordination with the World Bank TA. The outputs 
must be designed to complement and enable the execution of the rural WSS strategy, under 
preparation. During the preparation of each output, the key local stakeholders need to be 
consulted to ensure strong local ownership. The TA will result in the following outputs: 
(i)  Output 1: Rural water supply and sanitation policy adopted. Adoption of a rural 
WSS policy will give the institutions in the rural WSS subsector the mandate, 
authority, and tools needed to manage the development of rural WSS and improve 
service delivery.   
(ii)  Output 2: Capacity development program developed. This program will ensure 
that the roles and responsibilities of all rural WSS institutions are clearly defined. 
Furthermore, it will provide these institutions with the required skills to fulfill their 
roles and responsibilities effectively. 
(iii)  Output  3:  Framework  for  infrastructure  development  and  system 
maintenance developed. This framework will improve the technical operations in 
the rural WSS sector. O&M guidelines will ensure sustainable and efficient delivery 
of services. A new design approach, technical standards, procurement plans, and

5 
mechanisms to minimize corruption will ensure new infrastructure is well designed, 
cost-effective,  efficient  to  operate,  and  effectively  procured.  Technical 
improvements  will  be  monitored  through  an  information  gathering  and 
benchmarking  plan.  Consistent  service  delivery  will  be  enforced  through  the 
service standards. 
  
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The TA is estimated to cost $810,000 of which $750,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-V). The government will provide 
counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff and their travel and per diem, office facilities, 
meeting  avenues  for  workshops,  and  other  in-kind  contributions.  The  cost  estimates  and 
financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  SACCS will be the TA executing agency and the Department of Drinking Water Supply 
and Sewerage Development will be the implementing agency. The government will form a 
working group that includes the Prime Minister’s Office, Ministry of Finance, and SACCS. This 
group will approve the TA outputs and promote proposed reforms of WSS. 
 
20.  ADB will engage individual consultants to implement the proposed TA, in accordance 
with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as  amended from time to time). 
Individual consultants are being used rather than a firm in order to (i) increase the speed of 
procurement, (ii) obtain a specific mix of skills, and (iii) eliminate any undue influence on the 
outputs from local design institutes. Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance 
with the Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
21.  A  team  of  international  consultants  (21  person-months)  and  national  consultants 
(18 person-months) will develop the TA outputs. The team will include four international and 
three national consultants. The consultants should have expertise in regulatory and institutional 
matters, communications, finance, economics, WSS, and Kyrgyz law. The outline terms of 
reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. 
 
22.  The  TA  will  follow  the  standard  monitoring  and  supervision  procedures  for  ADB-
administered TA. Good practice and lessons will be disseminated through policy dialogues with 
the government and in seminar and training materials and knowledge products published under 
the TA. An evaluation of performance and outcomes will be carried out at the end of the TA and 
reflected in the TA completion report. 
 
23.  The TA will be implemented from May 2013 through November 2014. Final outputs will 
be available in November 2014. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
24.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic for the Water Supply and Sanitation Strategy, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants 
 
1.  Regulatory and institutional specialist and team leader (9.5 person-months). The 
consultant should have a master’s degree in commerce, social sciences, or engineering, with 12 
years of experience in regulation and institutional development. Proposed activities for this 
position are to: 
(i)  ensure  close  coordination  with  the World  Bank  technical  assistance  (TA)  to 
prepare the rural water supply and sanitation (WSS) strategy;  
(ii)  ensure all outputs enable the execution of the rural WSS strategy; 
(iii)  analyze the weaknesses and strengths of the existing institutional models; 
(iv)  review  the  institutional  design  of  demonstration  projects  and  determine  the 
sustainability of these designs;  
(v)  prepare the institutional framework for the rural WSS sector;  
(vi)  determine the capacity development needs of the rural WSS institutions and 
deliver the essential training for these institutions; 
(vii)  lead the preparation of the rural WSS policy and prepare the service monitoring 
mechanism,  sector  coordination,  knowledge  sharing  and  WSS  professionals 
training plans, and capacity development implementation plan to modernize and 
upgrade skills of people working in WSS; and 
(viii)  prepare and deliver training to institutions implementing the rural WSS policy, 
and monitor implementation of the policy. 
 
2.  Key deliverables for this position are: 
(i)  inputs to the report on project lessons;  
(ii)  inputs to the demonstration project assessment report;  
(iii)  final rural WSS institutional framework and corresponding capacity development 
plan; 
(iv)  draft service monitoring mechanism, sector coordination and knowledge-sharing 
plan, WSS professionals training plan, and capacity development implementation 
plan for the implementation of the rural WSS policy;  
(v)  final rural WSS policy; and 
(vi)  rural WSS policy implementation report. 
 
3.  Communication  specialist  (2.5  person-months).  The  consultant  should  have  a 
master’s degree in social sciences or arts (communications) with 10 years of experience in 
development communications. Proposed activities for this position are to 
(i)  gather  community  feedback  on  demonstration  projects  and  prepare  public 
awareness campaign;  
(ii)  assist in the preparation of rural WSS subsector coordination and knowledge 
sharing plan, focusing on communication between entities and dissemination of 
knowledge; and 
(iii)  coordinate  with  the  World  Bank  TA  and  ensure  communications    are  also 
supportive of the rural WSS strategy. 
 
4.  Key deliverables for this position are: 
(i)  inputs to the report on project lessons;  
(ii)  inputs to the demonstration project assessment report; and

12  Appendix 3 
(iii)  assist in the analysis of data and support the preparation of the final deliverables; 
and  
(iv)  assist in monitoring the implementation of rural WSS policy. 
 
10.  Key deliverables for this position are: 
(i)  inputs to the report on project lessons;  
(ii)  inputs to the demonstration project assessment report;  
(iii)  inputs to the rural WSS institutional framework;  
(iv)  inputs to the rural WSS policy; and 
(v)  inputs to the rural WSS policy implementation report.  
 
11.  Water supply and sanitation engineer (6.0 person-months). The consultant should 
have a master’s degree in engineering with 15 years experience in WSS engineering. Proposed 
activities for this position are to 
(i)  assist the international WSS engineer by gathering and analyzing data required; 
and  
(ii)  support in the preparation of the final deliverables.  
 
12.  Key deliverables for this position are: 
(i)  inputs to the report on project lessons;  
(ii)  inputs to the demonstration project assessment report; and 
(iii)  inputs to the rural WSS policy. 
 
13.  Lawyer (2.0 person-months). The consultant should have a master’s degree in law 
with 10 years experience in policy and legislation development. Proposed activities for this 
position are to 
(i)  analyze the existing legal framework and note areas where existing laws create 
constraints to sector development; 
(ii)  advise on the legal status of the rural WSS institutions, propose any laws that are 
needed to operationalize the rural WSS institutional framework, and prepare key 
clause for these laws;  
(iii)  advise how proposed rural WSS policy  will interact with the existing Kyrgyz 
legislation; and 
(iv)  maintain legal compatibility of outputs under this TA with rural WSS strategy. 
 
14.  Key deliverables for this position are: 
(i)  inputs to the rural WSS institutional framework; and 
(ii)  inputs to the rural WSS policy.
